page.title: 16ECOLOGY OF THE SOUTH CLIFFS
page.content: The cliffs are approximately 300ft high,though no more than 150ft in the vertical plane. The steep lower section is formed by wave action which also produced the wave-cut platforms and stacks (the Pea Stacks off Jerbourg Point,Cradle Rock in Moulin Huet Bay (Moolin Wet) and the Dog and Lion rocks further to the west).The hogback upper sections culminate in a plateau.The rock is of metamorphic origin,predominantly gneiss.The thin acid soil supports a great variety of plants;many are species not found in Great Britain.{PLANTS}The mild climate of the area allows plants to over-winter well and flowers are present nearly all year round.In Spring,the cliffs are covered with Narcissi and in the sheltered areas there are primroses,violets and rare ferns.Numerous types of grasses can be
